abstract.p: Daylight–electric light integrated schemes encompassing soft computing models have been perceived as a lucrative option for lighting energy conservation. This paper exploits the quintessence of design and real-time implementation of an adaptive predictive control strategy for robust control of a daylight–electric light integrated scheme. To elicit daylight variations, occupancy detection and user preferences an online self-adaptive, predictive control algorithm is structured for real-time control of electric lights and window blinds. The adaptive, predictive model entails integration of an online, adaptive daylight illuminance predictor in conjunction with an electric light intensity control algorithm for interior illuminance regulation and a fuzzy-logic based window blind control algorithm to eliminate glare and solar heat gain. The control algorithm modelled with real-time sensor information administers an online process of identification, prediction and parameter adaptation. The prototype controller is successfully implemented in a test chamber. A real-time user-friendly simulator provides an online visualisation of illuminance performance indicators and control of the process. The anticipated synergetic effects of the online control algorithm validated in the test chamber highlights the benefits of the scheme in terms of glare control, illuminance uniformity and energy efficiency.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: At present, the increased emphasis on energy efficiency and visual comfort has brought particular attention to daylighting in commercial buildings. A coordinated control strategy for electric light and window blind control in a daylight–electric light integrated scheme affords the prospect of substantially reducing lighting energy requirements. The impact of manual control of window blinds on annual energy consumption has been investigated in Toronto, Canada by Newsham.1 The assumptions made in his study were: The room is occupied between 08:00 hours and 17:00 hours, the occupants would lower the blinds to avoid thermal discomfort if solar radiation exceeded 233 W/m2 and the electric lighting would be turned off if the horizontal work plane illuminance exceeded 500 lx, the results indicated an increase in lighting and heating energy consumption of 66% and 17%, respectively, and a decrease in cooling energy consumption by 7%. Overall the total energy consumption was increased by 33%. These results confirm that a blind system by itself, without a proper control, will not contribute to energy savings.

Lee et al.2 examined the potential energy saving of automated Venetian blinds operating in synchronisation with daylighting controls in Oakland, California. The full-scale Oakland Federal Building demonstration facility was constructed to measure the electric lighting power consumption and the cooling energy produced by the window and lighting systems. The facility consisted of two adjacent identical rooms (4.57 m × 3.71 m × 2.68 m). For evaluation, each room was equipped with a ‘base case’ system and ‘dynamic’ system. For the base case system, the Venetian blind was set to one of three static positions throughout the day to simulate manual control: 0° (horizontal), 15° (partly closed) and 45° (nearly closed). For the dynamic system, a ‘prototype system’ was developed to activate the blind every 30 s in order to block the direct solar radiation and maintain a daylight illuminance of 540–700 lx. The range of blind motion was restricted to 0° to 68° to limit sky view and glare. This study concluded that the prototype system could achieve energy savings of 7% to 15% and 19% to 52% for cooling and lighting energy, respectively, compared to a static 45° angle. However, because the automated blind system developed only blocked the solar radiation, similar to that of Newsham1 study, it can be disadvantageous where the heating load is dominant. In other words, the optimisation of blind systems can only be achieved if a criterion for selecting control variables is performance–based rather than rule-based.

Recent literature has proposed the application of artificial intelligence techniques as an efficient tool to redress the drawbacks of current conventional lighting and window blind controllers. For instance, the International Energy Agency project3,4 and research by Chang5 and Bauer et al.6 have all shown that soft computing techniques (SCTs) are a promising technology with respect to complex integrated and adaptive control problems encountered in building lighting management systems.

A fuzzy logic-based control algorithm to minimise thermal and electric lighting energy demand in a building was first developed by the Technical University of Vienna.6 However, this focused mainly on energy conservation. Guillemin et al.7 examined a fuzzy logic-based system for integrated control of blinds, electric lighting and heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems. To achieve self-adaptation, an artificial neural network and genetic algorithms were employed. This technique meant the system was capable of adapting to user behaviour and the room characteristics. The adaptive controller in this study was split into two parts based on user presence: Visual comfort was optimised on detection of occupancy, otherwise energy saving was optimised. The method was tested in two rooms (4.75 m × 3.6 m × 2.8 m with a south facing window covered with textile blinds) representing the integrated and a conventional system. The conventional system was examined without blind or dimming control, while in the integrated system the blinds were lowered or retracted by fuzzy logic rules without slat angle control. Owing to the predictive ability of the controller, the integrated system reduced energy consumption by 25% over 94 days compared to the conventional system. However, this approach7 does not reflect the transient behaviour of the system.

In a real-time environment, Lah et.al.8 implemented a fuzzy logic-based automatic illuminance control in a test chamber of dimensions (1 m × 1 m × 1 m) with an window opening equipped with a roller blind on the south side. The notion was to regulate interior daylight illuminance by application of fuzzy logic rules based on interior luminous efficacy, external global solar radiation and interior illuminance.8

In a simulated environment, Kurian et al.9 explored building energy savings using fuzzy logic-based blind and artificial lighting control in Manglore, South India. The possible positions of the blinds were closed, opened, or partially closed to reduce glare and solar heat gain, and to provide uniformity of daylighting. An adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference scheme (ANFIS) was used in the daylight–electric light integrated scheme for adaptation to variations in environments and room characteristics. Using dimming control the electric lights were fully on, off, or in-between to satisfy the illuminance criteria of 400 lx. The fuzzy logic-based window blind controller was operated according to three modes: If the user is absent, the energy optimisation mode is used; if the user is present, the visual comfort mode can be used and, if the user is present both the visual and thermal comfort mode can be used. The simulation results9 indicated that the integrated fuzzy logic-blind controller with daylighting controls could achieve 20–80% of annual energy savings compared to the base case of manual blind systems without daylighting control. Similar to Guillemin et al.7, the blind control in Kurian et al.9 was limited to position control (lowered/retracted) without any variation in slat angle.

Following these objectives, an experimental setup is realised; a prototype design is developed and tested in real-time for adaptive, predictive coordination and control of automated lights as well as window blinds as per user presence and preferences. Unlike some of the studies mentioned above that used offline daylight illuminance data sets and models, this paper presents a real-time, adaptive, predictive light control scheme modelled with real-time measurements, online performance predictors and design procedures that yields robust controller performance. The adaptable control parameter structures address practical issues concerning the real-time implementation of the scheme. The parameters of the controllers are updated online to minimise the error in prediction as well as control. The advantages of online self-learning and model parameter tuning characteristics ensure that the developed model can adjust continuously to variations in climate, building characteristics and user preferences.

sec.title: 2. Problem statement
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows a block diagram of the daylight–electric light integrated control scheme with its control loop for electric light and window blind control. It should be noted here that the blind control and lighting control are separately treated. Accordingly, on detection of occupancy, the process entails automatic adjustment of blind slat angles for glare reduction and regulation of set point illuminance by variation of electric lights to supplement the available interior daylight illuminance. The current scheme is a multiple input single output (MISO) system. Details of the scheme are given in Table 1. The control parameters are split into three components: Input variable, controlled variable and manipulated variable. The input to the system comprises: (a) daylight on the window, chiefly climate data in the form of exterior vertical global and diffuse illuminance, (b) occupancy detection and (c) user wishes. The measurable variables of exterior illuminance (Eext), interior ambient illuminance (Eint) and occupancy sensing are related to the sensor measurements, respectively. These measured input variables characterise perturbations to the interior illumination process. The variable to be controlled is the average interior task illuminance. Regulating the intensity of electric light and the varying the window blind slat angle are the manipulated variables. The control problem for the present scheme is to maintain the interior task illuminance close to a reference level with visual comfort, uniformity and energy effectiveness. Figure 1
Basic control scheme for daylight–electric light integration

The adaptive, predictive scheme discussed in this paper encompasses: (a) an ANFIS interior daylight illuminance predictor model in conjunction with an ANFIS inverse electric light intensity control algorithm for interior illuminance regulation and (b) a fuzzy logic-based window blind control algorithm to prevent glare and solar heat gain. The developed ANFIS light controller maintains a base level of illumination using as much daylight as possible and shuts the electric lights off when spaces are unoccupied or the illuminance exceeds the reference value. The fuzzy logic-based window blind control prevents glare by automatically adjusting blind slat angles using the concept of sky ratio (SR). To obtain robust controller performance, the parameters of the proposed controller are updated online to minimise the prediction and control error. The objective is to harness the benefit of hybridisation between machine learning techniques and the real-time sensor information to construct effective online electric light and window blind controllers for achieving visual comfort, illuminance uniformity and energy efficiency in the visual control domain of commercial buildings. The emphasis is on creating a competent, online, adaptive, predictive model for real-time adaptation to dynamic environmental variations in a daylight–electric lighting integrated scheme.

Figure 2 shows the design concept of the experimental system. For predictive control, inputs to the system are exterior daylight on the window, occupancy and a user defined set point illuminance also known as user wishes. The components of the projected automated system primarily contain: A PC data acquisition (DAQ) input–output board, an exterior daylight sensor for measuring outdoor vertical global illuminance plus diffuse illuminance on the window, interior photocells that read ambient illuminances, occupancy sensors for presence detection, 1–10 V analog electronic dimming ballasts (EDB) for controlling fluorescent lamp light output, on/off relays for light switching and finally two 12 V dc motors for blind up/down movement and slat angle variation. Design concept of experimental system for adaptive predictive electric light and window blind control

sec.title: 3. Experimental procedure
sec.p:
This section provides an insight into the test set up in the research test chamber and related equipments used in this research. A test chamber (Figure 3(a)) constructed on the roof of the New Lecture Hall building of Manipal Institute of Technology, Manipal, India is used for education and research on building daylight harvesting systems. The site is chosen to ensure that direct solar radiation is not obstructed by trees, buildings or any other objects during the measurement period. Figure 3(b) portrays a plan view of the test chamber. The test chamber is based on common office building applications having dimensions of 4 m × 4 m × 2.3 m with four windows (1.3 m × 1.3 m) of clear glass (80% transmittance); each integrated into one face of the façade, the four facing the cardinal directions north, south, east and west. A single window Venetian blind of dimensions 1.3 m × 1.3 m is mounted on the inside of each window. The window blinds are of the semi-specular white aluminium type containing a multiple series of horizontal slats of negligible thickness and evenly spaced apart by 2.1 cm. The blinds are controlled to produce three tilt angles namely: 0° (full open with blind slat horizontal), 45° (inclined to horizontal) and 90° (full closed with blind slats vertical). In order to eliminate glare, the blinds can be lowered fully down or raised fully up to entirely cover or uncover the window. For presence detection, a ceiling mounted occupancy sensor is positioned at the centre of the ceiling. Conceptually, the room is segregated into two equal parts: The front half which is closer to the window and the rear half, to account for the two lighting zones in each cardinal direction. The electric lamps arranged in each zone are dimmable to supplement daylight. For brevity, Figure 3(b) depicts the two lighting zones for either north or south facing windows. For experimentation with north or south facing windows, luminaires L1 and L2 are independently controlled in each zone while luminaires L3 and L4 remain switched off. For east and west facing windows luminaires L3 and L4 are controlled with L1 and L2 switched off. Figure 3(b) also indicates the position of the exterior daylight illuminance sensor and the disposition of the photocells in the interior. Sixteen interior ambient photocells are spaced apart by 1.0 m in a grid. Of these 16 ambient sensors, eight (P1 to P8) are at a work plane height of 0.7 m from the floor. The remaining eight photocells (P9 to P16) are mounted on the ceiling directly above these task sensors. The interior illuminance measurements are made separately at these ceiling and task level grid points. The electrical lighting system comprises of four Osram 2 × 36 W CFL lamps each housed in a mirror optic luminaire operating on analog 1 V to 10 V EDB. In each zone, directly beneath the lamps the maximum and minimum desktop illuminance from the electric lighting alone is 740 lx and 50 lx, respectively, corresponding to 100% and 30% of the ballast dimming voltage. The exterior global and diffuse vertical illuminance is recorded using BF3 sunshine sensors mounted on the roof of the test chamber free from obstructions. In the interior, 16 Hamamatsu S7686 Si-photodiodes are used as photosensors. The Honeywell passive infra-red occupancy sensor is deployed to detect motion in the controlled area. Daily energy consumption is recorded onto a computer hard disk by a Selec MFM-383 energy meter with a RS 485 communication feature for a PC interface. The electrical energy related parameters are logged into the PC in an Excel spreadsheet format which can be easily imported into Matlab. For the purpose of DAQ; a DAQ compatible with Matlab software has been designed and fabricated with a serial communication feature. The illuminance sensor data are logged to the computer disk every second to create daily files of values, averaged over 15 s, of exterior and interior illuminance, respectively. This sampling time is chosen to facilitate prediction of ambient daylight illuminance in addition to triggering a control signal every 5 minutes for demonstration purpose. It is to be noted that the provision is made in the concept to set other user preferred timings for automated control operation of lights and window blinds. Figure 3
A display of set up in the test chamber: (a) photograph of test chamber with windows on each façade facing four cardinal directions and exterior sensor mounted on the roof top and (b) plan of test chamber interior depicting arrangement of four luminaires, occupancy sensor and the disposition of exterior as well as interior illuminance sensors. Photocells are distanced 0.5 m from window wall and 1 m between one another

sec.title: 4. Control scheme design
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows a simplified functional block diagram illustrating the control scheme of the integrated ANFIS light and fuzzy logic window blind controller that utilises real-time sensing techniques. Figure 4
Simplified functional block diagram illustrating the control scheme of integrated ANFIS light and fuzzy logic window blind controller

sec.title: 4.1. Online ANFIS controller for electric light control
sec.p:
The developed ANFIS controller with the structure shown in Figure 5 is composed of an online process identifier plus a five step ahead interior illuminance predictor concatenated with an ANFIS inverse based electric light control signal generator. This closed loop approach achieves its goal by utilising a prediction of the system output based on the internal model of the process. The ANFIS modelling approach described here serves two objectives: (a) it provides a basic model for illuminance system identification that depicts the behaviour of the underlying system and (b) applies the ANFIS inverse model to the controller design. The process identifier is crucial for the successful estimation and tuning of the adaptive controller parameters. Since, the ANFIS electric light controller attempts to maintain a constant desired illuminance on the working plane daylight represents a perturbation signal for the controller. The electric light intensity control represents a process whose mathematical model is unknown. Therefore, the applied control structure necessitates inverse modelling of the process. Figure 5
Block diagram depicting online ANFIS process identification, prediction and control

A control scenario as given in Table 2 is hypothesised to realise a nonlinear relationship between the collected interior illuminance data and the control signals. To achieve a nonlinear controller, the ANFIS system is trained to learn the inverse dynamics of the electric light process. Assuming that the inverse of the process exists, define the illuminance data set acquired from sensors as E(k) and the dimming control signal for the EDB as u(k) to establish the inverse mapping f. To obtain the inverse models, control signals to the dimming ballast can be articulated as an explicit function of the past, present and next step ambient illuminance values E. The inverse model has two inputs E(k) and E(k+5) and the output u(k) is the control action to the EDB as given by equation (1) (1)u(k+5)=G(E(k+5),E(k)) Table 2

Equation (1) is used to treat the time varying illuminance dynamics and to generate control actions. The control signals are generated every 5 minutes based on the five step ahead interior illuminance predictor output. Accordingly, the ANFIS inverse controller triggers a control signal to the dimming ballast over a range 30% to 100% to account for ambient daylight variation within 100% to 30% of the set level as illustrated in Table 2. If the available daylight illuminance Etask goes above Es, the corresponding control signal will be 0 and the lights will be fully off. If Etask becomes less than 0.2Es, the lamps are at full light output with a control signal value of 1. In between this boundary, the control signal is generated by the formula [1-(Etask/Es)], which enables the entire space to have a desired illuminance profile as specified by the user at any time instant k.

The illuminance training data set covers the time span from 1 June 2010 to 1 October 2010. All the data sets are sampled with 15 s averages for 24 hours daily. An ANFIS with three g-bell membership is used for training and identification of process dynamics. The trained ANFIS model therefore has a total of nine fuzzy rules with a total of 35 fitting parameters of which 16 are premise parameters and 24 are consequent parameters. The root mean squared error (RMSE) and step size graph of the model are displayed in Figure 6. It is observed that at the end of 15 epochs, the RMSE of both the training and test data set is approximately 0.014. This negligibly small RMSE indicates that ANFIS has captured the essential behaviour of underlying system. Additionally, very similar values of RMSE for both the test and training data sets indicate that the model exhibits a good generalisation capability. As illustrated in Figure 6, model learning is almost complete after the initial 14 epochs of training and therefore model training is stopped at 40 epochs. Moreover, after epoch number 38, the step size reduces to 0.008. Figure 6
Error curves and step sizes for the designed ANFIS inverse model

sec.title: 4.2. Fuzzy logic-based window blind control
sec.p:
Shading systems like Venetian blinds are beneficial particularly in the tropics and in the summer season, to restrict solar heat gain and glare from direct sunlight. Altering blind slat angle allows adjustment of daylight level and distribution in interiors and the controlling of glare due to excessive illuminance on the window.10 In this study, a fuzzy logic-based window blind control algorithm is developed taking into account the tropical climate of South India. The objective is to stop discomfort glare due to daylight by automating variations of slat angle and up–down movements of the Venetian blinds. Seeing that the control variables are continuous and simultaneous human interactions are involved, fuzzy logic is considered a good solution to this conceptual scheme. Human interactions are considered in the form of occupancy as well as user preferences. Exterior vertical illuminances on the window provide timely information and the best indication of glare.11 In this study daylight on the window in terms of vertical global and diffuse illuminance is selected as the main input for the window blind controller, making it different from other models.6–9 Real-time exterior daylight sensor data is employed to estimate global and diffuse illuminance. The daylight on the window is experimentally assessed in terms of SR which is the ratio between the exterior diffuse illuminance to the exterior global illuminance. The subjective response in the test chamber indicated that SR < 0.6 caused discomfort glare from the window, especially, for SR < 0.3 because then the sun is at low altitudes shining directly in front of the window. This experimental observation is in agreement with the field study conducted by Reinhart and Voss12 regarding blind closing actions where subjects closed the blinds to eliminate daylight glare. Conversely, SR > 0.6 creates a sensation of diffuse daylight entering the interiors. As depicted in Table 3, the designed automatic motorised Venetian blind system algorithm lowers the blind and adjusts the blind slat angles in the presence of glare. But, during the non-glare period, the window blinds are raised up admitting diffuse daylight into the interior. This unique design model based on the SR concept eliminates unnecessary window blind movements to avoid glare. It was observed during experiments in the clear sky condition that SR < 0.6 prevails from about 07:30 hours to 11:30 hours for the east facing window and after 13:00 hours to 17:30 hours for the west facing window. The north facing window receives diffuse daylight throughout the day and hence at all times SR > 0.6. For the south facing window SR < 0.6 persists from 07:30 hours to 17:30 hours inducing discomfort glare. Table 3
Window blind control scheme for designing fuzzy logic window blind control

In this study, the role of the fuzzy control algorithm is to produce appropriate signals for Venetian blind slat angle positioning so as to eliminate daylight glare. The primary reason for choosing the fuzzy logic controller is: (a) the control strategy can be represented by a set of rules and (b) the controller does not essentially require the exact set of equations to represent the system. These reasons allow the designer to change the basic characteristics of the controller with minimal effort i.e. simply by redefining the rules. Figure 7 shows the internal structure of fuzzy logic controller and its method of application to control the window blind. As mentioned above, daylight glare depends on the exterior vertical illuminance. For this reason, a unique rule base is formed for the process with the input fuzzy variable as SR and window blind position as the output variable. Figure 7
Block diagram for fuzzy logic window blind controller

sec.title: 4.2.1. Fuzzy membership functions
sec.p: The first step in the fuzzy controller design involves specifying the control inputs as well as output variables and their domains. The numeric input variable measurements are transformed by fuzzification into the fuzzy linguistic variable. The present design utilises triangular membership functions for both the input and output linguistic variables. In the antecedent part, the input variables are divided into three steps and in the consequent part into three steps.

sec.title: 4.2.2. Decision making
sec.p: On the basis of the preliminary experiments and the observations in the test chamber, a set of linguistic rules was designed. Three rules could be formulated with the input variables being assigned to the input linguistic variables. These rules are framed with a simple IF-THEN structure based on Table 3. The premise (IF-part) describes a certain situation in the form of a fuzzy specification of measured exterior global and diffuse illuminance values. The conclusion (THEN-part) specifies an appropriate fuzzy output in terms of blind slat angle position. In the IF-THEN rules, the fuzzy subsets and set are combined with the logical fuzzy operations such as AND, OR and NOT. The fuzzy logic controller discussed in this study incorporates Mamdani’s Min operation as an inference method. This implication has a simple min–max structure encompassing two phases of operations. In the first phase, the two input variables are involved with min-operation, hence the antecedent pair in the rule structure are constructed by logical AND. Then all the rules are aggregated using max operation.

sec.title: 4.2.3. Defuzzification
sec.p: Defuzzification is the process for transforming the fuzzy control statement into specific control actions. Actual slat angle is determined by the proportion of defuzzified value. The PC generated digital control output from the fuzzy logic controller of the PC is transmitted to the DAQ to activate the window blind motor driver relays. Referring to Table 3, in order to position the blind slat angles at either 0° or 45° or 90°, a digital value ranging from [0:250:500] from the controller drives the blind slat angle positioning motor. Accordingly, a 10 K, 10 turn rotational potentiometer13 measures and feeds back the blind slat angle value to the PC for the comparison process. Additionally, a digital value ranging from [0:10 000] lowers or raises the blind to cut-off or admit daylight into the interior. In this study, the operation of raising or lowering the blind completely requires approximately 10 s. In order to carry out this operation, a delay of 10 000 ms is provided in the microcontroller corresponding to a digital control value of 10 000.

sec.title: 5. Results
sec.p:
The proof-of-concept trials were performed in the dedicated daylighting laboratory described in Section 3. This section illustrates the validation of ANFIS lighting and fuzzy logic window blind controller, respectively, in an attempt to regulate set point task level illuminance and avoid daylight glare. The artificial light and window blind control algorithms discussed in Sections 3 and 4 respectively, are integrated in the Matlab environment. For real-time implementation Matlab tool boxes namely: Fuzzy logic, ANFIS, graphical user interface (GUI) and DAQ are employed. The GUI permits manual entry of user preferred illuminance, visualisation of sensor input data and monitoring of various control scenarios. The default value of the set point illuminance is 500 lx. The illuminance training data set covers the time span from 1 June 2010 to 1 October 2010. All the data sets are sampled using 15 s averages for 24 hours daily. A real-time validation process for checking the prototype controller performance was performed from 2 October 2010 to 10 November 2010. For elucidation, the results presented for a south facing window for a typical office working hours from 08.00 hours to 17.00 hours (local time) Monday to Saturday. Figure 8 illustrates the system functionality in two zones of the test chamber on 11 December 2010 and 12 December 2010. For validation, the task illuminances are determined at two reference positions (points 5 and 7) in each lighting zone at a work plane height of 0.7 m above the floor centred with respect to the window as shown in Figure 3. For the purpose of this discussion, this paper considers the target minimum average illuminance on the task area is 500 lx, as is consistent with many lighting standards.14 For demonstration purposes, the dimming control operates every 5 minutes to regulate the set point task illuminance. Furthermore, the controller switches off the electric lights when the space becomes unoccupied for more than 10 minutes commencing from the last presence detection by the occupancy sensor. In response to the real-time exterior illuminance portrayed in Figure 8(a) the proposed fuzzy logic-based automatic motorised Venetian blind system algorithm lowers the blinds and adjusts the blind slat angles in the presence of glare and raises the blind during non-glare as depicted in Figure 8(b). Figure 8(c) and (d) show the interior illuminance variation in the two zones, respectively. Moreover, Figure 8(c) and (d) shows how the ANFIS control system attempts to preserve 500 lx on the task area by supplementary electric light when there is a daylight deficit. If the interior daylight is less than the target illuminance of 500 lx, the ANFIS controller tops up the electric lighting to meet user defined illuminance on the work plane. Referring to Figure 8(d), the controller independently activates the actuators in the two zones to turn on the lights when the daylight illuminance is less than 450 lx on the task. Likewise, lights are turned off when the daylight illuminance exceeds 550 lx on the task. Hence, the consequent parameters of ANFIS controller are updated online by a recursive least square estimation algorithm if the system tracking error exceeds ± 10% of set point illuminance. In the two zones, every 5 minutes, the sensor values are fed back and compared to the target values. When the feedback value exceeds the target level, no control signal is generated and the lights are switched off. Alternatively, the controller triggers an analog control signal voltage through the PC DAQ to the dimming ballast in order to regulate the set point illuminance. In the control algorithm, priority is set to create an optimum illuminance condition at the task surface. During the control interval, the ANFIS controller transmits an eight bit digital value in the range [0:255] from the PC to the DAQ, corresponding to 0% to 100% dc control voltage to the EDB. Figure 8
Integrated real-time performance of ANFIS light and fuzzy logic window blind controller depicted for south facing window with continuous data monitoring on 11 December 2010 and 12 December 2010: (a) exterior vertical global and diffuse illuminance profile and (b) performance profile of fuzzy logic window blind controller illustrating window blind slat angle variation to eliminate glare. In zone 1 and zone 2 profile of: (c) interior predicted unregulated and regulated illuminance and (d) performance of ANFIS light controller depicting percentage dimming control voltage generated to EDB

The total electricity consumption includes rated energy consumption by the two luminaires employed in the two lighting zones of the test chamber. Hence, the base case is represented by a lighting power consumption rated at 144 W without dimming controls. Mean monthly energy savings were measured from 25 November 2010 to 25 February 2011 for a working day ranging from 08.00 hours to 17.00 hours while maintaining the desired illuminance of 500 lx for each window orientation, respectively. It is to be noted that all the measurements were carried out with only one window open at a time, i.e. with the remaining three windows closed. Table 4 presents that the proposed controller produced approximately 30% to 42% lighting energy savings with a illuminance uniformity above 0.8. The uniformity of illuminance in the interior is measured by the task level photosensors described in Section 3. These values can be regarded as an indication of the likely energy savings from the proposed light control algorithm. The energy savings can be mainly attributed to the tropical climate of South India, occupancy dependent lamp switching as well as the use of an efficient lamp and dimming ballast.15 Table 4

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p:
Energy saving can be attained from dimming/switching of electric lighting as a function of ambient daylight. The ambient daylight illuminance is often time dependent and nonlinear. Designing a satisfactory control system necessitates precise online identification between the real and identified model. In this paper, an adaptive predictive control using an ANFIS model is proposed. To evaluate the applicability of the proposed control method, model experiments in real-time conditions were performed. The measurement data used for online modelling and control are obtained directly from an external sunshine sensor and interior photosensors interfaced to a PC. The proposed automated system maintains a base level of illumination supplementing the interior daylight. Additionally, the controller is programmed to shut electric lights off when spaces are unoccupied or the illuminance exceeds the prescribed reference level. The developed controller realises illuminance uniformity above 0.8. The analysis is provided during office working hours for a period of 4 months from 08:00 hours to 17:00 hours (local time). The performance of the proposed control scheme implies that the energy savings obtained are likely to occur irrespective of the type of the luminaires, light sources and other electronic components used and may possibly reach above 30% which is very important in terms of energy savings. Intensive analysis and improvements in the automatic lighting control strategies are imperative for successful daylight harvesting. Considering this paper in the above context, future research work may be required to address the following issues and challenges:
The implemented system presented in this paper has focused on the electric light and window blind control algorithm in the visual environment of a building. Extension of the system’s applicability to thermal aspects involves incorporation and integration of online adaptive predictive HVAC control algorithm together with the lighting control for a building energy management system. In this paper only three blind slat angles of 0°, 45° and 90° have been considered for avoiding daylight glare. Fuzzy logic-based intermediate slat angle positioning could be considered for achieving both visual and thermal comfort. How extensively the system architecture must be restructured and/or extended to cover these other building control domains remains to be further investigated.
The controllers described in this paper are a PC based system utilising the control algorithms coded using Matlab software. The developed neuro-fuzzy codes could be deployed on to the embedded system or on FPGA circuits using advanced techniques to envisage high performance at low cost. The related issues are currently being investigated by many researchers.
Wireless sensors and actuators could also be integrated with the scheme.
The researchers are currently working on the camera-based system for the lighting and shading control. The notion behind the concept is that high dynamic range imaging technology has the potential to replace the conventional multiple photosensors and occupancy sensors to replicate the operation of occupancy sensing and control of artificial light as well as window blinds.
The current scheme implementation needs to be extended to electrical lighting energy management in larger buildings by taking into account the appropriate aspects of building networking techniques and communication protocols. This also requires the development of a global control algorithm which could handle potential conflicts among different control zones.

As a concluding remark, this paper extracted the essence of adaptive control theory and advanced SCTs to develop an innovative intelligent light and window blind control algorithm for a daylight–electric lighting integrated scheme. In order to ensure that daylighting in buildings would become the preferred option in this millennium, it is necessary to optimise energy savings by taking into account the integration of daylight, advanced control algorithms and occupant response. It is envisaged that knowledge transfer of this underlying concept to design professionals and industry will aid in the development of advanced building energy management systems.
